The morning dew clung to the petals of Marcus Thornfield's prize-winning dahlias like tiny diamonds, each droplet catching the early sunlight that filtered through the ancient oak trees bordering his modest garden in Westerville. He knelt beside the flower bed, his weathered hands gentle as they guided the stems into perfect alignment, humming an old melody whose origin escaped him completely. The tune felt familiar yet foreign, like a half-remembered dream that dissolves upon waking.

"Beautiful work, as always," called his neighbor Mrs. Henderson from across the low stone wall that separated their properties. She was hanging washing on the line, her movements efficient despite her seventy-odd years. "Those dahlias are going to be the talk of the village show again this year."

Marcus straightened slowly, brushing soil from his knees with a practiced motion. "Thank you, Mrs. Henderson. Though I sometimes wonder if there's more I should be doing with them." He paused, staring at the flowers with an expression of puzzlement that crossed his features more frequently these days. "Strange thing is, I keep having these dreams about being on stage somewhere, surrounded by lights and crowds. Probably just my imagination running wild."

The elderly woman's expression shifted slightly, becoming more guarded. "Dreams can be peculiar things, Marcus. Sometimes it's better not to dwell on them too much." She quickly gathered her washing basket and hurried inside, leaving Marcus standing alone among his flowers with questions forming in his mind like morning mist.

The postman arrived precisely at nine o'clock, as he had every weekday for the past eighteen months since Marcus had moved to Westerville. The village was small enough that everyone knew everyone else's routines, and Thomas Fletcher had been delivering mail along these winding lanes for nearly three decades. He approached Marcus's cottage with an unusual spring in his step, clutching an envelope that seemed to practically glow with importance.

"Morning, Marcus! Got something rather special for you today," Thomas announced, barely containing his excitement. The envelope was thick, cream-colored, and bore an official-looking seal that caught the light. "Looks like it might be from one of those television production companies. You haven't been entering competitions without telling anyone, have you?"

Marcus accepted the envelope with trembling fingers, studying the return address with a frown of concentration. The letters seemed to swim before his eyes for a moment, and he experienced that peculiar sensation he'd grown accustomed to—the feeling that something important was just beyond his grasp, like trying to catch smoke with bare hands. "I don't recall entering anything, Thomas. My memory isn't quite what it used to be."

"Well, open it then! Don't keep an old man in suspense," Thomas urged, his eyes bright with curiosity. In a village where the most exciting event was usually the annual flower show, a mysterious official letter was entertainment of the highest order.

Marcus carefully opened the envelope, his movements deliberate and precise. The letterhead bore the logo of Britain's Got Talent in bold, colorful letters, and as his eyes scanned the formal text below, his face grew pale. The words seemed to leap from the page: "Congratulations... finalist position... live final... previous application approved..."

"Good heavens," he whispered, sinking onto his garden bench as the reality of the situation began to penetrate. "They want me to compete in the final of Britain's Got Talent. But I never... I can't remember applying for anything like this."

Thomas peered over his shoulder, reading aloud in an excited voice. "It says here that your audition was exceptional and that the judges are looking forward to your return performance. Return performance? Marcus, have you been keeping secrets from us?"

The gardener shook his head slowly, his mind struggling to process the information. Fragments of images flashed through his consciousness—bright lights, a massive audience, the sound of applause thundering through a vast auditorium. But these seemed like scenes from someone else's life, disconnected from his quiet existence tending flowers in Westerville. "I honestly don't know what to make of this, Thomas. It feels like a mistake, but..."

"But what if it isn't?" Thomas interrupted, his voice full of encouragement. "What if this is your chance at something extraordinary? You've got talents that go beyond gardening, Marcus. I've seen the way you work with plants, the way they seem to respond to you. There's something almost magical about it."

Marcus looked down at his hands, calloused and stained with earth, trying to imagine them creating something worthy of a national television audience. The letter mentioned that transportation and accommodation would be provided, and that he would need to prepare for a live performance in front of millions of viewers. The very thought made his pulse quicken with a mixture of terror and inexplicable excitement.

"The thing is," he said slowly, "reading this letter feels familiar somehow. Like I've read these words before, or words very similar to them. But that's impossible, isn't it? I would remember something as significant as appearing on television."

Thomas studied his friend's face with growing concern. Everyone in Westerville knew about Marcus's memory problems, the result of what the doctors had described as a traumatic brain injury from an accident he couldn't recall. The gardener had arrived in their village eighteen months ago with little more than the clothes on his back and a head full of gaps where his past should have been. The local doctor had explained that such amnesia wasn't uncommon after severe trauma, and that memories might return gradually, if at all.

"Perhaps," Thomas suggested gently, "this is connected to your life before the accident. Maybe you did audition for the show, and now they're following up. It would explain why you can't remember applying."

The possibility hung in the air between them like morning fog, heavy with potential and uncertainty. Marcus read through the letter again, noting details he had missed in his initial shock. The production team expected him to arrive in London in exactly one week. They mentioned that his "signature performance" had been one of the most memorable auditions of the season. Most puzzling of all, there was a reference to "defending your unique position in the competition."

"Defending my position?" Marcus murmured aloud. "What could that possibly mean?"

Mrs. Henderson appeared at her kitchen window, ostensibly washing dishes but clearly eavesdropping on the conversation. Her expression was troubled, and she seemed to be debating whether to intervene. Finally, she called out across the garden wall, "Marcus, dear, might I have a word with you privately?"

Thomas took the hint and gathered his mail bag with obvious reluctance. "You'll let me know what you decide, won't you? The whole village will be talking about this by teatime." He hurried away down the lane, already composing the story he would tell at every house on his route.

Mrs. Henderson emerged from her cottage and approached the wall separating their gardens. Her face was creased with worry, and she clutched a dish towel in her arthritic hands. "Marcus, I need to tell you something. I probably should have mentioned it before, but the doctors said it was better to let you recover naturally, without pressure."

"What is it, Mrs. Henderson?" Marcus asked, though something in her tone made him wonder if he truly wanted to know.

"Last year, around this time, I remember watching Britain's Got Talent. There was a performer, a man who did the most incredible things with plants and flowers. He could make them bloom instantly, create the most beautiful arrangements right there on stage. The audience was completely mesmerized." She paused, studying his face carefully. "Marcus, that man looked exactly like you. Same height, same build, even the same way of moving. But his name was different—Marcus Thornfield, they called him. And he won, Marcus. He won the entire competition."

The dish towel fluttered to the ground as the implications of her words settled between them. Marcus felt the world tilt slightly, as if the earth beneath his feet had shifted. The fragments of memory that had been haunting him—the lights, the crowds, the overwhelming sense of performing—suddenly took on new meaning.

"You're saying that I might be last year's winner?" he asked, his voice barely above a whisper. "But if that's true, why can't I remember? And why would they invite me to compete again?"

Mrs. Henderson shook her head helplessly. "I don't know, dear. But I do know that after the finale aired, that performer seemed to disappear completely. No interviews, no appearances, nothing. It was as if he vanished into thin air. And then, just a few months later, you arrived here with no memory of your past."

Marcus sank back onto his garden bench, the letter still clutched in his hand. If Mrs. Henderson was right, then his entire understanding of himself was built on quicksand. The quiet life he had constructed in Westerville, the simple pleasure he found in tending his garden, the sense that he was starting fresh after some unnamed tragedy—all of it might be an elaborate fiction constructed by his damaged mind.

"There's something else," Mrs. Henderson continued reluctantly. "During the competition, there was another performer. A man who seemed to have similar abilities with plants, though not quite as developed as... as the winner's. He came in second place, and I remember thinking at the time that he looked absolutely furious about losing. The cameras caught him arguing with the winner backstage after the finale. It was quite uncomfortable to watch."

"Do you remember his name?" Marcus asked, though he wasn't entirely sure he wanted to know.

"Sebastian Thorne, I think it was. Rather dramatic-looking man with dark hair and intense eyes. The judges seemed to find him charming, but there was something about him that made me uncomfortable. Too smooth, if you know what I mean."

The name Sebastian Thorne sent an unexpected chill down Marcus's spine. It meant nothing to his conscious mind, but somewhere deeper, in the places where memory and instinct intersected, alarm bells began to ring. He had the sudden, irrational urge to lock his doors and draw his curtains, as if speaking the name had somehow summoned a threat.

"Mrs. Henderson," he said slowly, "if what you're suggesting is true, then this letter isn't an invitation to compete. It's an invitation to return and defend a title I don't remember winning."

"That would seem to be the case, yes." She bent to retrieve her fallen dish towel, her movements stiff with age and anxiety. "The question is, what are you going to do about it?"

Marcus looked around his peaceful garden, taking in the neat rows of vegetables, the carefully tended flower beds, the small greenhouse where he nurtured seedlings with infinite patience. This life felt real and solid in a way that the glittering world of television and competition did not. Yet the letter in his hand represented a connection to his lost past, possibly the only chance he might ever have to understand who he had been before the accident.

"I suppose," he said finally, "I'll have to go to London and find out the truth."The decision to travel to London felt both inevitable and terrifying as Marcus spent the following days preparing for what might be the most important week of his life—or perhaps the most important week he would experience for the second time. The very uncertainty of his situation created a strange duality in his mind, where every practical preparation felt simultaneously familiar and foreign. He found himself packing clothes he didn't remember buying, including a dark green jacket that seemed to call to him from the back of his wardrobe, its fabric soft with wear and its pockets containing soil stains that spoke of countless hours spent working with plants.

Mrs. Henderson had insisted on helping him prepare, though her assistance came with a constant stream of worried commentary about the wisdom of his decision. She pressed homemade sandwiches wrapped in brown paper into his hands and fretted about whether he was taking enough medication for the headaches that still plagued him on difficult days. "You must promise to call if anything feels wrong," she insisted, adjusting his collar with the maternal efficiency of someone who had raised five children. "Television people can be quite ruthless, and in your condition, with your memory still so fragile, they might try to take advantage."

The train journey to London passed in a blur of countryside that seemed to trigger half-formed memories with every mile. Marcus found himself pressing his face to the window like a child, watching familiar landmarks that he couldn't quite place, experiencing the unsettling sensation of déjà vu that had become the soundtrack to his existence. Other passengers came and went at various stops, but he remained fixated on the passing scenery, searching for some definitive proof that he had traveled this route before. The rhythm of the wheels on the tracks seemed to whisper secrets in a language he had forgotten how to understand.

As the train pulled into King's Cross Station, Marcus felt his pulse quicken with what could have been excitement or anxiety—the two emotions had become indistinguishable in recent days. The production company had arranged for a driver to meet him, and he spotted his name written on a neat placard held by a smartly dressed woman who seemed to recognize him the moment he approached. "Mr. Thornfield," she said with a warm smile that didn't quite reach her eyes, "welcome back. I'm Sarah Chen from the production team. I hope your journey was comfortable."

The phrase 'welcome back' hung in the air between them like a question mark, and Marcus found himself studying her face for signs of familiarity. Sarah was perhaps thirty years old, with short black hair and the kind of efficient elegance that suggested she was very good at her job. She moved through the crowded station with practiced ease, guiding him toward a waiting car while maintaining a steady stream of cheerful conversation about the weather, the traffic, and the excitement building around the upcoming final. Yet beneath her professional demeanor, Marcus detected something that might have been curiosity, or perhaps concern.

The hotel they had booked for him was in Bloomsbury, a elegant Georgian building that seemed to exist in its own pocket of calm amid the chaos of London traffic. His room was on the fourth floor, overlooking a quiet square where plane trees filtered the afternoon sunlight into dancing patterns on the pavement below. As Sarah handed him his room key and a thick folder of information about the following week's schedule, she hesitated for a moment, as if debating whether to say something more personal than the standard production company pleasantries.

"Mr. Thornfield," she began carefully, "I worked with you during your initial audition process last year, and I have to say, you seem... different somehow. More relaxed, perhaps? The last time we met, you were quite intense about the competition, very focused on winning at any cost. This version of you seems much more at peace." She paused, studying his face with professional interest. "I hope you don't mind me saying so, but the change is quite striking."

Marcus set down his small suitcase and turned to face her fully, sensing an opportunity to learn something crucial about his forgotten past. The woman clearly knew him, or at least knew the person he had been before the accident, and her observations might provide valuable insights into the man he used to be. "Sarah, I hope you'll forgive me for asking, but do you remember much about how I was during that time? The truth is, I've had some memory problems recently, and I'm trying to piece together what happened."

Her expression shifted from professional courtesy to genuine concern, and she closed the hotel room door behind her before responding. The action suggested that what she was about to say was not meant for public consumption, and Marcus felt his heartbeat accelerate with anticipation. "Memory problems? That would certainly explain the change in your demeanor. Last year, you were like a man possessed, completely driven by the need to prove something. You barely slept, barely ate, and you spent every free moment practicing your routines with an intensity that honestly worried some of us on the production team."

She moved to the window, gazing out at the quiet square below as if gathering her thoughts. The afternoon light caught the concern in her features, revealing someone who took her responsibility for the show's contestants seriously. "There was also the situation with Sebastian Thorne, of course. The rivalry between you two became quite toxic by the end of the competition. He seemed to take your success as a personal affront, and you... well, you weren't exactly gracious about having a clear advantage over him."

The mention of Sebastian Thorne sent that same inexplicable chill through Marcus's system, accompanied now by flashes of imagery that felt like memories trying to surface. He saw a tall, dark-haired man with piercing eyes and an smile that seemed to promise unpleasant consequences. The vision was accompanied by a sense of unease so profound that Marcus had to sit down on the edge of the bed to steady himself. "What kind of rivalry?" he managed to ask, though part of him dreaded the answer.

Sarah turned from the window to study him with growing alarm. His face had gone pale, and his hands were trembling slightly as they gripped the hotel bedspread. "Are you alright? Should I call someone?" When he shook his head and gestured for her to continue, she moved closer, her voice dropping to little more than a whisper. "Both of you claimed to have the same abilities—this almost supernatural connection with plant life. You could make flowers bloom instantly, create elaborate living sculptures in minutes, even heal damaged plants with just a touch. But your power was clearly stronger, more refined, and Sebastian couldn't stand being second best."

The images in Marcus's mind were becoming more vivid now, accompanied by sensations he couldn't quite categorize. He remembered the feeling of energy flowing through his hands into waiting soil, the sensation of connecting with something vast and green and alive that responded to his will like an extension of his own body. The memories were intoxicating and terrifying in equal measure, suggesting abilities that seemed to belong more to the realm of fantasy than reality. "Did anyone ever question how we were able to do these things? Did it seem... normal to everyone else?"

Sarah laughed, but there was no humor in the sound. The question seemed to unlock something she had been holding back, and she began pacing the small hotel room with nervous energy. "Normal? Nothing about either of you was normal, Marcus. The producers were thrilled because you were both clearly genuine—no tricks, no stage magic, just raw ability that defied explanation. The audience ate it up, of course. In an age of digital effects and manufactured entertainment, here were two people doing things that seemed genuinely impossible."

She stopped pacing and fixed him with an intense stare that made Marcus feel as though she was trying to see inside his mind. Her next words came out in a rush, as if she had been holding them back for months. "But there were incidents, Marcus. Things that happened backstage that never made it into the broadcast footage. Plants in the studio would wither and die when Sebastian was angry. The green room had to be replanted three times during filming because something about the energy between you two was affecting everything living in the vicinity."

The revelation hit Marcus like a physical blow, confirming suspicions he hadn't even been fully conscious of having. The control he exercised over his garden in Westerville, the way plants seemed to flourish under his care beyond all reasonable expectation, the strange dreams of performing before vast audiences—all of it was connected to abilities that apparently defied the natural order. Yet even as the truth began to crystallize in his mind, questions multiplied like weeds in spring rain.

"Sarah," he said slowly, "if all of this is true, then why don't I remember any of it? And more importantly, why has the show invited me back? Surely the winner of last year's competition wouldn't be eligible to compete again."

The production assistant's face went through a series of expressions—surprise, confusion, and finally a kind of dawning horror that made Marcus's stomach clench with dread. She pulled out her phone and began scrolling through what appeared to be official documents, her movements becoming increasingly frantic as she searched for information. "Marcus, I think there's been a terrible mistake. According to our records, you didn't win last year's competition. Sebastian Thorne was declared the winner after you... after you disappeared."

The words hung in the air like smoke from a fire that had consumed everything Marcus thought he understood about his situation. If he hadn't won the competition, then Mrs. Henderson's memory was faulty, and his entire theory about his past was built on false foundations. Yet the alternative—that Sebastian Thorne had somehow claimed victory in his absence—raised even more disturbing questions about what had happened during those lost months between the competition and his arrival in Westerville.

"Disappeared?" Marcus repeated, his voice sounding strange and hollow to his own ears. "What do you mean, disappeared?"

Sarah's phone trembled in her hands as she continued reading from the official records. The afternoon light streaming through the hotel window seemed to dim, as if the sun itself was reacting to the revelations unfolding in the quiet room. "According to this, you left the studio after the final performance and never returned. The judges had to make their decision without you present, and Sebastian was declared the winner by default. There was a police investigation, but no trace of you was ever found."

The implications crashed over Marcus like a cold wave, washing away the last remnants of the simple narrative he had constructed about his life. He wasn't returning to defend a title he had won; he was returning to complete a competition he had fled from for reasons he couldn't remember. The invitation that had seemed like a gift from his forgotten past was beginning to feel more like a trap, carefully baited with his own lost identity.**Chapter 2**

The morning after Sarah's revelations found Marcus standing before the mirror in his hotel bathroom, studying his reflection as if looking at a stranger. The face that gazed back at him seemed caught between two identities—the peaceful gardener he had become and the driven competitor he had apparently once been. His hands, still bearing the honest calluses of soil and honest work, trembled slightly as he attempted to shave with the precision his morning routine in Westerville had made automatic. The simple act of preparing for the day felt fraught with significance, as though each decision about his appearance might unlock memories that remained stubbornly buried beneath layers of amnesia and uncertainty.

Sarah had arranged to meet him in the hotel lobby at nine o'clock sharp, and as Marcus descended in the lift, he found himself wondering what other surprises the production team might have in store for him. The folder of information she had left contained a bewildering array of forms, schedules, and legal documents that seemed to assume a level of familiarity with television production that he simply didn't possess. Most disturbing of all was a medical waiver that specifically mentioned "unusual physical manifestations" and "potential environmental effects during performance," language that suggested the show's producers were well aware that their contestants possessed abilities far beyond the ordinary.

The lobby of the Georgian hotel buzzed with the quiet efficiency of London business, guests checking in and out with the practiced anonymity of frequent travelers. Sarah sat in a leather armchair near the entrance, her attention focused on a tablet computer that seemed to contain an endless stream of urgent messages. When she looked up and saw Marcus approaching, her expression was carefully neutral, but he could detect the undercurrent of concern that had characterized their conversation the previous evening. She had clearly spent the night researching his case, and the results of that investigation were written in the tense set of her shoulders and the way her eyes avoided direct contact with his.

"Good morning, Marcus," she said, rising from her chair with the kind of professional smile that had become her default expression around him. "I hope you slept well. We have quite a full day ahead of us, starting with a visit to the studio for technical rehearsals. The producers are eager to discuss your plans for the final performance, particularly given the... unusual circumstances surrounding your return to the competition."

They stepped out into the London morning, where the September air carried the first hints of autumn and the streets hummed with the energy of a city fully engaged in its daily business. The production company had arranged for another car, this one driven by a cheerful Cockney gentleman named Dave who seemed genuinely excited to be transporting a Britain's Got Talent contestant. His enthusiasm was infectious and slightly overwhelming, a steady stream of commentary about previous contestants he had driven, memorable performances from past seasons, and his own theories about what made for a winning act on the show.

"You're the plant man, aren't you?" Dave asked, catching Marcus's eye in the rearview mirror as they navigated through the increasingly heavy traffic toward the studio complex. "My missus saw your auditions on the telly last year, couldn't stop talking about it for weeks afterward. She's got quite the green thumb herself, you know, but nothing like what you were doing up there on stage. Made roses bloom right out of thin air, she said, beautiful as anything she'd ever seen."

The casual confirmation of his abilities from a complete stranger felt somehow more real than all of Sarah's official records and production notes. Dave's wife had witnessed his performances, had been moved by them, had carried the memory of them for an entire year. The knowledge should have been comforting, a connection to the person he had been before the accident, but instead it only deepened his sense of displacement. If his abilities had been so remarkable, so memorable, then why did using them now feel like learning a foreign language whose grammar he had once known by heart?

"Dave," Marcus said carefully, "do you remember anything about the final? About what happened to... to me after the last performance?"

The driver's cheerful demeanor shifted noticeably, his eyes meeting Marcus's in the mirror with a expression of genuine sympathy. The traffic around them seemed to slow, as if the city itself was listening to their conversation, waiting to hear secrets that had been buried for months. "That's the thing, isn't it? Nobody really knows what happened that night. One minute you were on stage doing something that looked like pure magic, the next minute you were gone. Just vanished without a word to anyone. The papers had a field day with it, all sorts of theories about stage fright and nervous breakdowns and such."

Sarah, who had been maintaining her professional silence in the front passenger seat, turned to face Marcus with an expression that seemed to be wrestling with conflicting loyalties. Her tablet had been pinging constantly with messages, and the tension in her posture suggested that the production team was dealing with complications beyond the normal challenges of organizing a live television finale. "Marcus, there's something else I need to tell you about this week's arrangements. Something that wasn't in the original invitation letter."

The car had entered the industrial area where the television studios sprawled across several city blocks, their bland exterior walls giving no hint of the entertainment empires housed within. Dave navigated through security checkpoints with practiced ease, his credentials clearly marking him as a regular contractor for the network. The guards at each gate seemed to recognize Marcus, their double-takes and whispered conversations suggesting that his return had been the subject of considerable speculation among the studio staff.

"What kind of something else?" Marcus asked, though the sinking sensation in his stomach suggested he might not want to know the answer. The accumulation of surprises and revelations was beginning to feel like a deliberate strategy, as though he was being fed information in carefully measured doses to prevent him from becoming overwhelmed and fleeing again.

Sarah's tablet chimed with another urgent message, and she glanced at it with obvious frustration before turning back to Marcus. Her professional composure was beginning to crack, revealing someone who was genuinely concerned about his welfare but constrained by obligations to her employers that might not align with his best interests. "Sebastian Thorne specifically requested that you be invited back. He's defending his title this year against a new crop of contestants, but he insisted that the competition wouldn't be legitimate unless you were given the chance to complete what you started."

The revelation hit Marcus like ice water, washing away any remaining illusions he might have harbored about the innocent nature of his invitation to return. Sebastian Thorne hadn't simply accepted victory by default; he had actively orchestrated Marcus's return, which suggested motivations far more complex and potentially dangerous than simple sportsmanship. The rivalry that Sarah had described the previous evening was apparently still very much alive in Sebastian's mind, despite the passage of an entire year.

Dave pulled the car into a designated parking space outside the main studio building, but made no move to get out. Instead, he turned in his seat to face both his passengers, his earlier cheerfulness replaced by something approaching paternal concern. The change in his demeanor suggested that he had been thinking carefully about their conversation during the drive, weighing his words before offering advice that might matter more than casual driver-to-passenger pleasantries.

"Listen, mate," he said directly to Marcus, his voice carrying the weight of genuine worry. "I've been driving for this show for nearly five years now, and I've seen all sorts of contestants come and go. Most of them are lovely people just trying to live their dreams, you know? But that Sebastian bloke... there's something off about him. Always has been. The way he looks at people, like he's calculating how they might be useful to him. And after you disappeared last year, well, let's just say he didn't seem as surprised as everyone else."

Sarah's tablet had gone silent, but her knuckles were white where she gripped it, suggesting that Dave's assessment aligned with concerns she wasn't authorized to voice officially. The parking lot around them was beginning to fill with other cars as the day's production schedule kicked into gear, but their vehicle remained an island of tense conversation amid the bustle of television industry efficiency.

"What do you mean, he didn't seem surprised?" Marcus asked, though he was beginning to suspect that each answer would only lead to more disturbing questions. The pieces of his forgotten past were assembling themselves into a picture that bore little resemblance to the simple narrative of competition and amnesia he had initially imagined.

Dave glanced around nervously, as if checking for eavesdroppers, before leaning closer to the backseat where Marcus sat. His voice dropped to barely above a whisper, and his words carried the weight of someone sharing information that might have professional consequences if overheard. "The night you went missing, I was waiting outside the stage door to drive you back to your hotel, same as I'd done for all the other live shows. Sebastian came out instead, alone, and told me you'd decided to walk back on your own. Said you needed some air to clear your head after the performance."

The driver paused, his weathered face creased with the memory of that evening, clearly still troubled by details that had bothered him for months. The sounds of the busy studio complex seemed to fade as Marcus focused on every word, sensing that this casual observation from a man whose job was simply to transport contestants might be the key to understanding what had happened during those lost hours.

"But here's the thing," Dave continued, "I'd been driving you for weeks by then, and you never walked anywhere if you could help it. Always said the London streets made you nervous, too much chaos and concrete, not enough growing things to keep you centered. So when Sebastian said you'd decided to walk, it struck me as odd. Very odd indeed."

Sarah finally spoke, her voice tight with implications she couldn't openly acknowledge. The revelation that Sebastian had been the last person to see Marcus on the night of his disappearance cast their current situation in an entirely new light, transforming what had seemed like a generous gesture of sportsmanship into something far more sinister. "Marcus, if you're having doubts about this whole thing, we could arrange for you to return home. I'm sure I could convince the producers that your health isn't up to the demands of live television."

The offer was tempting, representing a return to the safe, comprehensible world of his garden in Westerville where the most complex challenge was deciding which vegetables to plant for the autumn harvest. Yet even as part of him yearned for that simplicity, another part—the part that had spent months haunted by half-remembered dreams of stage lights and applause—knew that running away would solve nothing. The questions surrounding his disappearance and the mysterious abilities he apparently possessed would continue to plague him whether he was in London or hiding in his cottage.

"No," Marcus said finally, his voice carrying more conviction than he felt. "I need to know what happened. I need to understand who I was before the accident, and why Sebastian Thorne felt it necessary to bring me back."

Dave nodded approvingly, his expression suggesting respect for Marcus's decision even as his concern remained evident. The three of them sat in the car for another moment, each lost in their own thoughts about the day ahead and the complications it was likely to bring. The morning sun had climbed high enough to begin warming the interior of the vehicle, but Marcus felt cold, as though the proximity to answers about his past was somehow draining the warmth from his body.

"Right then," Sarah said, gathering her professional composure like armor. "Let's go meet the production team and see what they have planned for your return to the Britain's Got Talent stage."**Chapter 3**

The Britain's Got Talent studio complex sprawled before them like a small city dedicated entirely to the manufacture of dreams and entertainment, its gleaming facades and bustling courtyards somehow managing to feel both magical and industrial at the same time. Marcus followed Sarah through a maze of corridors that seemed designed to disorient visitors, their walls lined with photographs of past winners and memorable acts that had graced the show's stage over the years. Each image seemed to watch him as he passed, creating the unsettling sensation that he was walking through a gallery of ghosts, people whose moments of triumph or failure had been frozen in time for the entertainment of future contestants who might share their fate.

The rehearsal studio they entered was vast and echoing, its polished floors reflecting the harsh fluorescent lighting that made everyone's skin look slightly unnatural. Technical crew members moved about with the purposeful efficiency of people who had done this countless times before, adjusting cameras and testing sound equipment with the kind of casual expertise that made the complex machinery of television production appear deceptively simple. At the center of it all stood a figure that Marcus recognized immediately, despite having no conscious memory of their previous encounters—a tall, elegantly dressed man with silver hair and the kind of commanding presence that seemed to bend the very air around him to his will.

"Marcus Thornfield!" the man exclaimed, striding across the studio floor with arms outstretched in a gesture of welcome that somehow managed to feel both genuine and theatrical. "I'm Jonathan Carey, executive producer of this little circus we call Britain's Got Talent. I cannot tell you how delighted we are to have you back. Your return has generated more buzz among our production team than anything we've done in years, and that's saying something considering the caliber of acts we typically showcase."

The producer's handshake was firm and confident, the grip of someone accustomed to making decisions that affected the lives and careers of countless people. His eyes, however, studied Marcus with an intensity that suggested he was cataloging every detail of the gardener's appearance and demeanor, comparing the current version with memories of their previous interactions. There was something calculating in that gaze, the look of a man who understood that good television often required a certain amount of manipulation and manufactured drama, even when dealing with contestants who possessed genuinely extraordinary abilities.

"Mr. Carey," Marcus replied, attempting to match the producer's professional warmth while struggling with the disorienting sensation of being enthusiastically greeted by someone who felt like a complete stranger. "I have to admit, I'm not entirely certain what I'm doing here. My memories of the previous competition are quite fragmented, and I'm concerned that I might not be able to meet everyone's expectations for my return performance."

Jonathan's expression shifted slightly, revealing a flicker of something that might have been concern or perhaps merely the irritation of someone whose carefully laid plans were encountering unexpected complications. The morning dew clung to the petals of Marcus Thornfield's prize-winning dahlias like tiny diamonds, each droplet catching the early sunlight that filtered through the ancient oak trees bordering his modest garden in Westerville. He knelt beside the flower bed, his weathered hands gentle as they guided the stems into perfect alignment, humming an old melody whose origin escaped him completely. The tune felt familiar yet foreign, like a half-remembered dream that dissolves upon waking.

"Beautiful work, as always," called his neighbor Mrs. Henderson from across the low stone wall that separated their properties. She was hanging washing on the line, her movements efficient despite her seventy-odd years. "Those dahlias are going to be the talk of the village show again this year."

Marcus straightened slowly, brushing soil from his knees with a practiced motion. "Thank you, Mrs. Henderson. Though I sometimes wonder if there's more I should be doing with them." He paused, staring at the flowers with an expression of puzzlement that crossed his features more frequently these days. "Strange thing is, I keep having these dreams about being on stage somewhere, surrounded by lights and crowds. Probably just my imagination running wild."

The elderly woman's expression shifted slightly, becoming more guarded. "Dreams can be peculiar things, Marcus. Sometimes it's better not to dwell on them too much." She quickly gathered her washing basket and hurried inside, leaving Marcus standing alone among his flowers with questions forming in his mind like morning mist.

The postman arrived precisely at nine o'clock, as he had every weekday for the past eighteen months since Marcus had moved to Westerville. The village was small enough that everyone knew everyone else's routines, and Thomas Fletcher had been delivering mail along these winding lanes for nearly three decades. He approached Marcus's cottage with an unusual spring in his step, clutching an envelope that seemed to practically glow with importance.

"Morning, Marcus! Got something rather special for you today," Thomas announced, barely containing his excitement. The envelope was thick, cream-colored, and bore an official-looking seal that caught the light. "Looks like it might be from one of those television production companies. You haven't been entering competitions without telling anyone, have you?"

Marcus accepted the envelope with trembling fingers, studying the return address with a frown of concentration. The letters seemed to swim before his eyes for a moment, and he experienced that peculiar sensation he'd grown accustomed to—the feeling that something important was just beyond his grasp, like trying to catch smoke with bare hands. "I don't recall entering anything, Thomas. My memory isn't quite what it used to be."

"Well, open it then! Don't keep an old man in suspense," Thomas urged, his eyes bright with curiosity. In a village where the most exciting event was usually the annual flower show, a mysterious official letter was entertainment of the highest order.

Marcus carefully opened the envelope, his movements deliberate and precise. The letterhead bore the logo of Britain's Got Talent in bold, colorful letters, and as his eyes scanned the formal text below, his face grew pale. The words seemed to leap from the page: "Congratulations... finalist position... live final... previous application approved..."

"Good heavens," he whispered, sinking onto his garden bench as the reality of the situation began to penetrate. "They want me to compete in the final of Britain's Got Talent. But I never... I can't remember applying for anything like this."

Thomas peered over his shoulder, reading aloud in an excited voice. "It says here that your audition was exceptional and that the judges are looking forward to your return performance. Return performance? Marcus, have you been keeping secrets from us?"

The gardener shook his head slowly, his mind struggling to process the information. Fragments of images flashed through his consciousness—bright lights, a massive audience, the sound of applause thundering through a vast auditorium. But these seemed like scenes from someone else's life, disconnected from his quiet existence tending flowers in Westerville. "I honestly don't know what to make of this, Thomas. It feels like a mistake, but..."

"But what if it isn't?" Thomas interrupted, his voice full of encouragement. "What if this is your chance at something extraordinary? You've got talents that go beyond gardening, Marcus. I've seen the way you work with plants, the way they seem to respond to you. There's something almost magical about it."

Marcus looked down at his hands, calloused and stained with earth, trying to imagine them creating something worthy of a national television audience. The letter mentioned that transportation and accommodation would be provided, and that he would need to prepare for a live performance in front of millions of viewers. The very thought made his pulse quicken with a mixture of terror and inexplicable excitement.

"The thing is," he said slowly, "reading this letter feels familiar somehow. Like I've read these words before, or words very similar to them. But that's impossible, isn't it? I would remember something as significant as appearing on television."

Thomas studied his friend's face with growing concern. Everyone in Westerville knew about Marcus's memory problems, the result of what the doctors had described as a traumatic brain injury from an accident he couldn't recall. The gardener had arrived in their village eighteen months ago with little more than the clothes on his back and a head full of gaps where his past should have been. The local doctor had explained that such amnesia wasn't uncommon after severe trauma, and that memories might return gradually, if at all.

"Perhaps," Thomas suggested gently, "this is connected to your life before the accident. Maybe you did audition for the show, and now they're following up. It would explain why you can't remember applying."

The possibility hung in the air between them like morning fog, heavy with potential and uncertainty. Marcus read through the letter again, noting details he had missed in his initial shock. The production team expected him to arrive in London in exactly one week. They mentioned that his "signature performance" had been one of the most memorable auditions of the season. Most puzzling of all, there was a reference to "defending your unique position in the competition."

"Defending my position?" Marcus murmured aloud. "What could that possibly mean?"

Mrs. Henderson appeared at her kitchen window, ostensibly washing dishes but clearly eavesdropping on the conversation. Her expression was troubled, and she seemed to be debating whether to intervene. Finally, she called out across the garden wall, "Marcus, dear, might I have a word with you privately?"

Thomas took the hint and gathered his mail bag with obvious reluctance. "You'll let me know what you decide, won't you? The whole village will be talking about this by teatime." He hurried away down the lane, already composing the story he would tell at every house on his route.

Mrs. Henderson emerged from her cottage and approached the wall separating their gardens. Her face was creased with worry, and she clutched a dish towel in her arthritic hands. "Marcus, I need to tell you something. I probably should have mentioned it before, but the doctors said it was better to let you recover naturally, without pressure."

"What is it, Mrs. Henderson?" Marcus asked, though something in her tone made him wonder if he truly wanted to know.

"Last year, around this time, I remember watching Britain's Got Talent. There was a performer, a man who did the most incredible things with plants and flowers. He could make them bloom instantly, create the most beautiful arrangements right there on stage. The audience was completely mesmerized." She paused, studying his face carefully. "Marcus, that man looked exactly like you. Same height, same build, even the same way of moving. But his name was different—Marcus Thornfield, they called him. And he won, Marcus. He won the entire competition."

The dish towel fluttered to the ground as the implications of her words settled between them. Marcus felt the world tilt slightly, as if the earth beneath his feet had shifted. The fragments of memory that had been haunting him—the lights, the crowds, the overwhelming sense of performing—suddenly took on new meaning.

"You're saying that I might be last year's winner?" he asked, his voice barely above a whisper. "But if that's true, why can't I remember? And why would they invite me to compete again?"

Mrs. Henderson shook her head helplessly. "I don't know, dear. But I do know that after the finale aired, that performer seemed to disappear completely. No interviews, no appearances, nothing. It was as if he vanished into thin air. And then, just a few months later, you arrived here with no memory of your past."

Marcus sank back onto his garden bench, the letter still clutched in his hand. If Mrs. Henderson was right, then his entire understanding of himself was built on quicksand. The quiet life he had constructed in Westerville, the simple pleasure he found in tending his garden, the sense that he was starting fresh after some unnamed tragedy—all of it might be an elaborate fiction constructed by his damaged mind.

"There's something else," Mrs. Henderson continued reluctantly. "During the competition, there was another performer. A man who seemed to have similar abilities with plants, though not quite as developed as... as the winner's. He came in second place, and I remember thinking at the time that he looked absolutely furious about losing. The cameras caught him arguing with the winner backstage after the finale. It was quite uncomfortable to watch."

"Do you remember his name?" Marcus asked, though he wasn't entirely sure he wanted to know.

"Sebastian Thorne, I think it was. Rather dramatic-looking man with dark hair and intense eyes. The judges seemed to find him charming, but there was something about him that made me uncomfortable. Too smooth, if you know what I mean."

The name Sebastian Thorne sent an unexpected chill down Marcus's spine. It meant nothing to his conscious mind, but somewhere deeper, in the places where memory and instinct intersected, alarm bells began to ring. He had the sudden, irrational urge to lock his doors and draw his curtains, as if speaking the name had somehow summoned a threat.

"Mrs. Henderson," he said slowly, "if what you're suggesting is true, then this letter isn't an invitation to compete. It's an invitation to return and defend a title I don't remember winning."

"That would seem to be the case, yes." She bent to retrieve her fallen dish towel, her movements stiff with age and anxiety. "The question is, what are you going to do about it?"

Marcus looked around his peaceful garden, taking in the neat rows of vegetables, the carefully tended flower beds, the small greenhouse where he nurtured seedlings with infinite patience. This life felt real and solid in a way that the glittering world of television and competition did not. Yet the letter in his hand represented a connection to his lost past, possibly the only chance he might ever have to understand who he had been before the accident.

"I suppose," he said finally, "I'll have to go to London and find out the truth."

The decision to travel to London felt both inevitable and terrifying as Marcus spent the following days preparing for what might be the most important week of his life—or perhaps the most important week he would experience for the second time. The very uncertainty of his situation created a strange duality in his mind, where every practical preparation felt simultaneously familiar and foreign. He found himself packing clothes he didn't remember buying, including a dark green jacket that seemed to call to him from the back of his wardrobe, its fabric soft with wear and its pockets containing soil stains that spoke of countless hours spent working with plants.

Mrs. Henderson had insisted on helping him prepare, though her assistance came with a constant stream of worried commentary about the wisdom of his decision. She pressed homemade sandwiches wrapped in brown paper into his hands and fretted about whether he was taking enough medication for the headaches that still plagued him on difficult days. "You must promise to call if anything feels wrong," she insisted, adjusting his collar with the maternal efficiency of someone who had raised five children. "Television people can be quite ruthless, and in your condition, with your memory still so fragile, they might try to take advantage."

The train journey to London passed in a blur of countryside that seemed to trigger half-formed memories with every mile. Marcus found himself pressing his face to the window like a child, watching familiar landmarks that he couldn't quite place, experiencing the unsettling sensation of déjà vu that had become the soundtrack to his existence. Other passengers came and went at various stops, but he remained fixated on the passing scenery, searching for some definitive proof that he had traveled this route before. The rhythm of the wheels on the tracks seemed to whisper secrets in a language he had forgotten how to understand.
